LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Socialist Republic of Viet Nam

Project Description  The Project will strengthen local management capacities and the 
institutional  framework  for  providing  sustainable  urban 
environmental services and improving urban infrastructure. It will 
improve  drainage,  sanitation,  and  solid  waste  systems  in  five 
provincial towns and one district level town in the central region of 
Viet  Nam,  where  inadequate  infrastructure  poses  serious 
environmental and health risks, and inhibits social and economic 
development. The towns are Dong Ha, Ha Tinh, Lang Co, Quang 
Ngai, Tam Ky, and Thanh Hoa.  The Project will also increase 
environmental  and  health  awareness  and  promote  the  active 
participation of citizens, particularly women and the poor, in urban 
management and services. 
   
Rationale  Following  many  years  of  rapid  urbanization,  the  level  of 
investment made for maintenance, repairs, and new capital works 
over the past decade in the urban sector has not been sufficient to 
provide the necessary urban infrastructure. Weak institutions, lack 
of  qualified  human  resources,  financial  constraints,  lack  of 
community  participation  and  slow  implementation  of  an 
appropriate legal framework for the urban sector have contributed 
to  the  low  coverage  and  inefficiency  of  urban  services.  This 
situation  has  led  to  serious  deficiencies  in  the  availability  of 
infrastructure and access to municipal services in urban areas, 
particularly for the poor. Although the Government and several 
funding agencies, including the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
have made efforts in recent years to improve the situation in the 
larger urban centers, provincial towns, particularly in the Central 
Region,  have  received  much  less  attention,  except  for  the 
improvement of water supply systems.  As a result, urban water 
pollution in Project towns in the Central Region has increased and 
flooding occurs frequently.

ii   
  The lack of adequate infrastructure and services in urban areas 
has  deteriorated  health  profiles  of  the  local  population, 
constrained investment and economic growth in the towns and the 
rural areas around them, accentuated poverty and vulnerability of 
the local population, and impacted on quality of life. Furthermore, 
lack  of  opportunities  in  the  towns  of  the  central  region  fuels 
migration  to  the  major  cities  of  Hanoi  and  Ho  Chi  Minh  City 
(HCMC),  increasing  problems  in  those  cities  and  promoting 
unbalanced regional development. 
 
Urgent  measures  are  necessary  to  address  deteriorating 
environmental conditions in urban centers and transform them into 
sources of economic growth and employment. ADB’s intervention 
is based on the necessity to (i)  improve urban infrastructure to 
sustain  economic  growth,  (ii)  promote  balanced  regional 
development, (iii) reduce poverty and vulnerability by improving 
environmental  and  health  conditions  in  urban  areas,  and  (iv) 
improve the sustainability and efficiency of urban services. The 
Project will increase the attractiveness of selected towns in the 
central region, helping them serve as counter-magnets for rural 
migrants  who  would  normally  move  to  Hanoi  or  HCMC  and 
improving  welfare  and  opportunities  for  residents  of  provincial 
urban centers. 
   
Objectives and Scope  The long-term project goals are to (i) improve the quality of life 
and health status of urban residents and reduce poverty in the six 
project towns and surrounding areas; and (ii) promote balanced 
regional economic development and  reduce migration from the 
central region to Hanoi and HCMC. The objective of the Project is 
to  improve  urban  environmental  conditions  in  project  towns. 
Project  outputs  include  (i)  expanding  and  upgrading  urban 
environmental  infrastructure;  (ii)  improving  autonomy  and 
managerial  and  technical  capacity  of  the  urban  environmental 
companies (URENCOs); (iii) improving urban management and 
planning  capacity  of  townspeople  committees  (TPCs); 
(iv) strengthening urban management policies through support to 
the newly established Department of Urban Infrastructure in the 
Ministry of Construction; (v) developing appropriate cost-recovery 
mechanisms  to  ensure  sustainability  of  urban  environmental 
services; (vi)  increasing community participation in the planning 
and management of urban services, particularly by the poor; (vii) 
enhancing public health awareness; and  (viii) enhancing the role 
of women in urban management and institutions.

iii 
 
   
   
The Project will comprise five parts: part A, awareness and pro-
poor sanitation; part B, drainage and flood protection; part C, 
wastewater  and  public  sanitation;  part  D,  solid  waste 
management;  and  part  E,  implementation  assistance  and 
institutional strengthening. The project area includes the provincial 
capital towns of Dong Ha, Ha Tinh, Quang Ngai, Tam Ky, and 
Thanh Hoa, and the district-level town of Lang Co. Part D will also 
include Chan May urban area, Phu Loc district town, and four 
communes in Phu Loc District of Thua Thien Hue Province. 
   
Cost Estimates  The total project cost, including physical and price contingencies, 
duties, taxes, and interest during construction, is estimated at 
$96.0  million  equivalent.  The  foreign  exchange  cost  is  $53.6 
million  equivalent,  or  55.8%  of  total.  The  local  currency  cost, 
including duties and taxes, is $42.4 million equivalent, or 44.2% of 
total. 
   
Financing Plan  It is proposed that ADB provides a loan of $44.0 million equivalent 
from its Special Funds resources to cover 45.8% of the total 
project cost. The ADB loan will have a maturity of 32 years, 
including a grace period of 8 years. It will carry an interest rate of 
1% during the grace period and 1.5% thereafter. The French aid 
agency, Agence Française de Développement (AFD), will provide 
a  loan  of  30  million  euros  ($31.8  million  equivalent)  for  joint 
financing of parts B, C, and E. The proposed AFD loan has two 
components: a normal loan (or PS1) of $26.5 million equivalent for 
physical works, and a concessional loan (or PTC) of $5.3 million 
equivalent for capacity strengthening activities. The PS1 loan will 
have a maturity of 20 years with a grace period of 7 years, and an 
interest rate of 2.5% for the entire term. The PTC loan will have a 
maturity of 30 years with a grace period of 10 years, and an 
interest  rate  of  1%  for  the  entire  term.  The  remaining  $20.2 
million, equivalent to 21.1% of the total project cost, is the local 
counterpart  contribution  financed  by  the  provincial  people’s 
committees (PPCs) and beneficiaries.

Project Benefits and  The Project will develop and expand urban services to poor and

Poverty rates in the six project towns are higher than the national

The Project will improve drainage and sewerage, reduce flooding, 
and benefit around 504,000 people. The Lang Co subproject will 
benefit an additional 158,000 permanent residents in Chan May 
town and Phu Loc district through the proposed regional solid

vi   
Risks and Assumptions  The main risks associated with the Project are (i) limited human 
resources and capacities of TPCs, URENCOs, and town-level 
women’s  unions  for  project  implementation;  (ii)  uncertainty 
regarding tariff increases necessary to ensure sustainability of 
urban services; (iii) insufficient community participation in project 
implementation, particularly from women and the poor; (iv) poor 
and vulnerable households negatively affected by resettlement; 
(v)  delays  caused  by  the  lack  of  experience  of  the  PMUs  in 
managing  an  ADB-funded  project;  and  (vi)  lack  of  local 
government ownership of sanitation facilities.  
 
The project incorporates mitigation measures to address these 
risks. They include (i) an institutional strengthening program for 
TPCs, URENCOs, and town-level women’s unions to increase 
their managerial and operational capacities; (ii) a detailed, time-
bound tariff increase program for urban environmental services 
affordable to all citizens and agreed by PPCs; (iii) a participation 
program, gender action plan, and public awareness campaigns 
included in the project design; (iv) a resettlement framework and 
resettlement  plans  to  ensure  that  affected  people  maintain  or 
improve their living standard after project completion; (v) the PCU 
and consultants with experience in implementing ADB-assisted 
projects will help PMUs establish effective project management, 
reporting, and bidding procedures; and (vi) local ownership is 
ensured  through  PPCs’  commitment  to  tariff  increases  and 
allocation of revenues for O&M.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on the proposed 
loan  to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Central  Region  Urban  Environmental 
Improvement Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  Following the request of the Government of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam (the 
Government),  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  technical  assistance  (TA)1 to 
prepare the Central Region Urban Environmental Improvement Project. The TA built on a 
previous ADB-supported TA2 study. The Project will contribute to the economic and social 
development of the central region of Viet Nam and promote balanced regional development. It 
will complement other ADB interventions in the region in the framework of the Country Strategy 
and Program (CSP) for Viet Nam.3 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
3.  Viet Nam’s population in 2003 is almost 80 million, about 20 million in urban areas. 
Urbanization  has  increased  markedly—from 20% in 1990 to about 25% in 2003—and the 
Government estimates that about 45% of the population will live in urban areas by 2020. Lack of 
sufficient land, capital investment, and employment opportunities in rural areas and towns in the 
central region  over the past decade have fuelled  migration to Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City 
(HCMC). The population of the two major cities increased about 1.5 times over the past 10 
years, and now accounts for almost 40% of the country’s total urban population. Hanoi and 
HCMC have attracted most foreign investment and assistance, adding to the attraction for rural 
migrants to these cities and harming balanced urban and regional development. Furthermore, 
rapid migration to the two major cities has caused deterioration of the urban environment, 
exacerbation of urban poverty, and worsening urban unemployment.  
 
4.  Despite substantial migration away from the central region over the past 10 years, that 
area’s urban  population  continues  growing  at  an  average  of  4.7%  a  year. In 1999, cities 
accounted for 20.6% of total population in the region compared to 17.5% 10 years earlier. 
During the last decade, the urban population of the region rose 56% to 4.5 million, compared 
with a national increase of 43%. Population in project towns has grown quickly and ranges from 
57,000 in Ha Tinh to 186,000 in Thanh Hoa, while the district town of Lang Co has about 11,000 
permanent residents. Urban poverty levels in the project towns are higher than the national 
average urban poverty level, ranging from 13.5% to 19.2%.  
 
5.  Urban infrastructure in the six project towns is unable to meet the growing demand 
because of lack of capital investment, lack of funds for maintenance, and weak institutional 
arrangements. Project towns have combined drainage systems in which wastewater and storm 
water are conveyed in common conduits then discharged in rivers or other watercourses. 
Coverage of the drainage systems in urban areas is very low, ranging from less than 0.1 meter 
(m) per capita in the district town of Lang Co to 0.2-0.4 m per capita in the provincial towns. 
Covered drains are usually limited to main roads in high- or medium-density areas. In the 
project towns, annual flooding occurs in more than 30–40% of the urban area. While around 
40% of households in provincial towns and 10% in the district town have septic tanks, only a few 
are connected to sewers or drains. Composting latrines and defecation in open areas are used 
instead. They create major health risks, particularly during floods. Solid waste is collected from

6.  Project  towns  require  improved  environmental  infrastructure  if  they  are  to  become 
effective centers of economic growth, attract investment, generate employment opportunities, 
and eventually draw rural migrants away from the magnet of Hanoi and HCMC. The five 
provincial capitals included in the Project need to improve their urban infrastructure systems and 
service coverage so that they can function as sustainable regional economic centers. Major 
tourism development planned for Lang Co over the next 5–10 years has potential to pollute 
beaches, waterways, and groundwater and will increase health risks unless steps are taken to 
upgrade sewerage and sanitation. One of the Government’s policy objectives is to address 
problems caused by migration to the major cities and correct the imbalance in living standards 
between the major cities and poorer areas in the central region.  Providing adequate urban 
infrastructure and services is a key factor in addressing the imbalance in regional development. 
The Project framework is presented in Appendix 1.  
 
7.  The Government selected the project towns based on a comparative analysis of towns in 
the 18 provinces in the central region. Selection criteria included (i) urban population growth, (ii) 
urban and rural poverty levels, (iii) economic development  potential,  and  (iv) infrastructure 
needs. The district town of Lang Co was selected as a pilot case for sustainable urban 
environmental management in a very small town because of its tourism potential. The five 
provincial capitals act as administrative and economic centers for their surrounding rural areas, 
and provide most of the nonagricultural employment in their provinces.   
 
8.  Since the mid-1980s, external funding agencies have provided loans of more than $700 
million for developing drainage, sanitation, and solid waste projects in Viet Nam. Approximately 
65% of this amount has financed environmental improvement projects in HCMC ($308 million) 
and Hanoi ($156 million). In provincial towns, external assistance has focused on water supply 
systems, but investment in drainage, sanitation, and solid waste improvements in the towns has 
been  relatively  small,  particularly  in  the  central  region.  Detailed  information  on  external 
assistance to Viet Nam’s urban sector is presented in Appendix 2. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
9.  The  key  problems  of  the  urban  sector  in  Viet  Nam  include  (i)  inadequate  capital 
investment in drainage, wastewater, sanitation, and solid waste systems; (ii) lack of central 
government guidance for urban management, slow implementation of policy reforms at the 
provincial  level,  and  an  incomplete  legal  framework;  (iii)  weak  and  unaccountable  urban 
institutions  and  poorly  defined  institutional  arrangements;  (iv)  inadequate  cost  recovery 
mechanisms to obtain sufficient financial resources for proper operation and maintenance 
(O&M);  (v)  insufficient  technical  and  managerial  human  resources  capacity  in  urban 
management and services agencies; and (vi) poor community awareness and participation in 
planning and management of urban services, particularly for women. A detailed urban sector 
analysis is presented in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
10.  Since  1990,  the  Government  has  introduced  policies  and  reforms  to  improve  the 
efficiency of the urban sector and promote urban development. The Comprehensive Poverty 
Reduction and Growth Strategy 2001–2010 mentions several objectives relevant to the urban 
sector, including  (i) promoting balanced and sustainable economic growth between regions;

3 
(ii) developing urban areas to create more jobs and improve living standards;4 (iii) strengthening 
environment protection and ensuring a healthy environment;5  (iv) promoting gender equity and 
enhancing the participation of women at all levels of leadership; (v) implementing fully  the 
decree on democracy at the grassroots level to improve people’s participation in local economic 
development; and (vi) strengthening accountability at all levels, especially local governments, by 
improving transparency of and publicity for local budgets. 
  
11.  The Government’s policies for urban development are presented in the Orientation Plan 
for Urban Development to 2020. The orientation plan’s objective is to progressively provide 
urban areas with appropriate modern infrastructure and a healthy environment to allow them to 
actively contribute to the country’s socioeconomic development. The policy gives emphasis to (i) 
developing  urban  centers  as  economic  growth  centers,  (ii)  developing  and  modernizing 
technical  and  social  infrastructure  to  attract  investment  and  improve  living  standards,  (iii) 
reducing gaps in economic development and living standards between urban and rural areas, 
and (iv) ensuring sustainable urban development by taking account of environmental factors 
and efficient use of natural resources. The plan recognizes the need to strengthen and improve 
the efficiency of urban management systems and policies.  
 
12.  The  Government’s  development  targets  and  policies  for  drainage  and  sanitation, 
reflected in the Orientation Plan for Urban Drainage Development to 2020 are to (i) improve and 
complete urban drainage and sewerage systems to ensure a minimum of 80–90% coverage by 
2020, (ii) require enterprises to have onsite treatment for toxic liquid waste, (iii) eliminate pit 
latrines in urban areas by 2005, (iv) provide waste collection systems that treat solid and liquid 
wastes,  and  (v)  gradually  rehabilitate  and  clean  the  canal  systems.  To  achieve  these 
development targets, the Government emphasizes the importance of institutional  reforms in 
developing efficient and sustainable water and sanitation sectors. Specifically, the orientation 
plans call for (i) restructuring the Ministry of Construction (MOC) to refocus its functions in 
development planning, sector policy formulation, regulations, training, and technology transfer, 
and terminating its direct involvement in business activities; (ii) clearly defining the roles and 
responsibilities of various Government agencies involved in the water and sanitation sector and 
encouraging better cooperation among these sector agencies; (iii) making provincial people’s 
committees  (PPCs)  the  responsible  agencies  for  water  supply,  sanitation,  and  drainage 
development  in  the  provinces;  (iv)  providing  training  and  capacity  building  on  project 
implementation  and  O&M  encouraging  service  providers  to  become  self-financing  and 
progressively  eliminating  subsidies;  (v)  creating  the  legal  basis  for  providing  public  urban 
services, with enhanced enforcement; (vi) promoting  community  education  and  awareness, 
particularly on drainage and sanitation issues; (vii) mobilizing additional financial resources; (viii) 
protecting water sources; (ix) upgrading technology and materials; and (x) developing human 
resources. 
 
13.  The Government’s urban solid waste management strategy, which lasts until the year 
2020, sets out Government objectives and policies for managing solid waste in urban areas. 
One of its targets is that cities and provincial towns will collect and dispose of at least 85% of 
urban and industrial solid waste in appropriate landfills by 2005, 90% by 2010, and 95% by 
2020. The strategy’s long-term objectives for 2020 also include strengthening solid waste 
management by (i) completing the legal framework to complement the Law on Environmental

14.  In June 1999, MOC issued guidelines for setting water supply and drainage tariffs. PPCs 
still hold authority to set tariffs, but the guidelines provide a framework and methodology for 
them to use in establishing these tariffs. A drainage charge is to be no lower than 10% of the 
total water production cost. However, the guidelines give no timeframe for applying the drainage 
charge. As a result, only a few provinces apply drainage and wastewater charges. At present, 
drainage charges are levied in only one of the six project towns: Tam Ky. However, even there 
the fees the PPC collects are not used for O&M for drainage and sewerage. For solid waste 
management, tariffs are set at levels that do not allow sufficient funds to be collected for proper 
O&M. Although the Government has introduced policies and reforms to improve the financial 
autonomy and sustainability of urban service providers—increasing cost-recovery through user 
charges and gradually eliminating central Government subsidies—existing policies have yet to 
be fully implemented at the provincial level. 
 
15.  Town people’s committees (TPCs) are responsible for administration in provincial and 
district towns. Most TPCs have established urban management divisions, but they lack capacity 
to perform because of scarce human resources. In many cases there is confusion between the 
role of the TPCs and the role of the departments of construction at the PPCs. TPCs do not have 
the  mandate  or  capacity  to  fix  or  assign  performance  standards to urban environmental 
companies (URENCOs) or to monitor their performance. Poor performance by the URENCOs 
and TPCs results in a general lack of trust from citizens and a reluctance to pay service fees. 
 
16.  Urgent measures are necessary to address deteriorating environmental conditions in 
urban centers and transform them into sources of economic growth and employment. The 
Project will help the Government achieve its objectives for the urban sector by (i) providing 
capital investment in urban areas of high government priority; (ii) supporting the preparation of 
national guidelines on urban management and facilitating the implementation of national policies 
at the provincial level; (iii) improving urban institutions capabilities and institutional framework for 
urban  environmental  management;  (iv)  establishing  financial  mechanisms  to  ensure 
sustainability and O&M of environmental urban services, (v) improving managerial and technical 
capacities of URENCOs and TPCs, and (vi) increasing community awareness and participation, 
particularly among women, in planning and managing urban services. A policy and institutional 
reform agenda is presented in Appendix 3. 
 
 17.  Lessons Learned. Some major lessons have been learned through implementing water 
supply  and  sanitation  projects  in  Viet  Nam  and  ADB  urban-sector interventions in other 
countries. One key lesson is that projects often face delays in establishing project management 
units (PMU), selecting consultants, acquiring land, resettling people, awarding contracts, and 
making  disbursements.  These  delays  have  increased  project  costs  and  frustrated  both 
beneficiaries and local authorities. There is a need for (i) greater delegation of authority to 
lower-level government agencies for implementation, with central Government ministries acting 
as  facilitators;  (ii) intensive  assistance  to  the  executing  agencies  in  project  planning  and 
management early during implementation; (iii) advance action for recruiting consultants; (iv) 
establishment of PMUs during project preparation; and (v) timely preparation for land acquisition 
and resettlement. Early and systematic training in Government and ADB procedures for all 
project  stakeholders—including  provincial  agencies,  consultants,  counterpart  staff,  and 
representatives of community groups—will be essential to minimize delays. 
 
18.  Previous projects yield further lessons that have been incorporated in the Project. Community-
based activities and public health awareness programs have not been optimized in previous projects 
because PMUs were reluctant to allocate funds, coordination was lacking among local institutions,

5 
public awareness programs were poorly timed, and consultations with communities were limited. A 
mechanism is needed to ensure appropriate attention to this component and facilitate coordination 
among local stakeholders. Institutional capacities and framework must be improved to ensure efficient 
urban management and service delivery. Easy-to-implement cost recovery mechanisms must be 
established and the resources collected should be used for proper O&M. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objective 
19.  The long-term goals of the Project are to (i) improve the quality of life and health status 
of urban residents and reduce poverty in the six project towns and surrounding areas, and 
(ii) promote balanced regional economic development and  reduce migration from the central 
region to Hanoi and HCMC. The objective of the Project is to improve urban environmental 
conditions in project towns.  
 
B.  Components and Outputs 
20.  Project outputs include (i) expanding and upgrading urban environmental infrastructure; 
(ii) improving autonomy and managerial and technical capacity of the URENCOs; (iii) improving 
urban management and planning capacities of the TPCs; (iv) strengthening urban management 
policies through support to the newly established Department of Urban Infrastructure in MOC; 
(v)  developing  appropriate  cost-recovery  mechanisms  to  ensure  sustainability  of  urban 
environmental  services;  (vi)   increasing  community  participation  in  planning  and  managing 
urban services, particularly by the poor; (vii) enhancing public health awareness; and (viii) 
enhancing the role of women in urban management and institutions.  
 
21.  The Project will comprise five parts: part A, awareness and pro-poor sanitation; part B, 
drainage and flood protection; part C, wastewater and public sanitation; part D, solid waste 
management; and part E, implementation assistance and institutional strengthening. The project 
area includes the  provincial capital towns of Dong Ha, Ha Tinh, Quang Ngai, Tam Ky, and 
Thanh Hoa, as well as the district-level town of Lang Co. Part D will also include Chan May 
urban area, Phu Loc district town, and four communes in Phu Loc District of Thua Thien Hue 
Province. A detailed description of the components is presented in Supplementary Appendix B. 
A brief description follows. 
 
1.  Part A: Awareness and Pro-poor Sanitation 
22.  Part  A  includes  (i)  a  community  awareness  and  participation  program  (CAPP), 
(ii) community-based sanitation (CBS), and (iii) a household sanitation program (HSP). It will 
target poor and low-income households, communities, neighborhoods, and households without 
appropriate access to urban sanitation. 
 
23.  The CAPP consists of (i) raising community awareness on sanitation and health, and 
working  with  URENCO  to  better  reach  female  staff  and  educate  landfill  scavengers  on 
occupational  health  hazards,  (ii)  raising  awareness  for  protecting  and  conserving  urban 
environmental  infrastructure,  (iii) motivating  households  to  connect  to  and  pay  for  urban 
environmental infrastructure and services, and (iv) informing potential beneficiaries on financial 
assistance available to improve community or household environmental sanitation. 
 
24.  The CBS aims to (i) improve community small infrastructure, and (ii) improve community 
participation and ownership in urban sanitation. The CBS will provide small grants, technical advice, 
and training for demand-driven, small-scale environmental sanitation improvements in urban areas 
not covered by other major infrastructure components. Community groups and neighborhoods will 
select, design, and implement local sanitation improvements, and will contribute to the works. 
 
25.  The HSP will provide grants, mostly to women, to help poor and low-income households 
within urban wards, to build septic tanks, toilets, and/or connect household wastewater to public

6 
drainage or sewage systems. The women’s union in each town will administer the  program and 
provide technical information to beneficiaries with the assistance of URENCOs and TPCs 
through the community management committee (CMC). 
 
2.  Part B: Drainage and Flood Protection 
26.  Part  B  includes  (i)  drainage  improvement,  and  (ii)  flood  protection  improvement. 
Drainage improvement will include improving flood regulating basins, rehabilitating and cleaning 
55  kilometers  (km)  of  existing  drains,  building  or  upgrading  60  km  of  primary  drains, 
constructing 175 km of secondary drains, and building 138 km of tertiary drains to convey storm 
water and wastewater to downstream outfalls. Major primary drains will follow existing drainage 
routes, and will consist of box culverts in densely populated areas, or open channels with raised 
embankments in low-density areas. Flood protection improvement will include building dikes 
and roads, 3.0 km and 2.8 km long respectively, in Tam Ky and Dong Ha towns to protect 
riverside communities from frequent river flooding. 
 
3.  Part C: Wastewater and Public Sanitation 
27.  Part C includes (i) wastewater improvement, and (ii) public sanitation. The wastewater 
component is designed to collect, treat, and safely dispose of wastewater from the urban areas 
in Thanh Hoa and Lang Co.  In Thanh Hoa, it includes building interceptor chambers on the 
combined drains, close to their discharge points, to divert flows to the interceptor sewer. It also 
includes 6 km of gravity sewers, 3 pumping stations, 3 km of sewage-rising mains to remove 
wastewater from the town, and a 13,500 cubic meter (m3)/day waste stabilization pond. In Lang 
Co, it will develop a separate sewerage system, comprising 28 km of sewers, 3 sewage-
pumping stations, 2 km of sewage-rising mains, a 4,750m3/day wastewater treatment plant, and 
a 1-km access road with an asphalt surface. The public sanitation component aims to improve 
public health and reduce pollution in the streets, canals, waterways, and lakes in project towns. 
For each town, it will introduce a septic tank management system; improve sanitation facilities in 
public areas such as markets, schools, bus stations, cultural centers, parks, and health clinics; 
and supply O&M equipment for sanitation. 
 
4.  Part D: Solid Waste Management 
28.  Part D will improve the collection, storage, and transport of municipal,  industrial and 
medical solid waste in the Project towns. It includes (i) upgrading and expanding sanitary 
landfills in Dong Ha, Ha Tinh, Quang Ngai, and Thanh Hoa and building a new landfill for Lang 
Co and Chan May towns, and Phu Loc district; (ii) upgrading 12.2 km of landfill access roads in 
four towns and building a 1.8-km access road to the landfill in Thanh Hoa; (iii) constructing 77 
local waste storage stations; and (iv) equipment for O&M of solid waste management system 
including 5 bulldozers, 5 excavators, 63 new compactor trucks, 560 handcarts, 99 pedicarts, 
and 9,875 portable storage bins. 
 
5.  Part E: Project Implementation Assistance and Institutional Strengthening 
Program 
29.  Part E includes project implementation assistance and an institutional strengthening 
program (ISP) for TPCs, URENCOs, MOC’s department of urban infrastructure, and town-level 
women’s  unions.  The  project implementation assistance program  includes  (i)  design  and 
construction supervision of urban infrastructure, social, gender, environmental, and resettlement 
aspects, as well as training and support for the project coordination unit (PCU) and PMUs; (ii) 
engineering and environmental surveys; and (iii) incremental administration support for allowances, 
vehicles, computers, and office equipment for PCU, PMUs, and town-level women’s unions. 
 
30.  The ISP includes (i) training for TPCs on urban management and planning, as well as 
service  contract  preparation  and  supervision;  (ii)  training  for  URENCOs  on  management

7 
information systems, asset management systems, administrative and financial management, 
social  and  gender  issues,  O&M  for  project  works,  planning,  budgeting,  communication 
techniques,  bookkeeping,  accounting  and  reporting;  (iii) technical  support  and  on-the-job 
training  to  MOC’s  department  of  urban  infrastructure  on  preparing  guidelines  on  urban 
management for provincial towns, and guidelines on drainage, sanitation, and solid waste tariffs, 
and organizing national workshops on urban management and financing; (iv) training in public 
health awareness, community-based sanitation, and a household sanitation program for each 
town’s women’s union, including coordinating, financial, and management opportunities; and (v) 
computer hardware and software for URENCOs.  
 
C.  Special Features 
31.  Poverty. The Project has been classified as a poverty intervention strategy, and will 
contribute to achieving the objectives of the Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth 
Strategy 2001–2010. The urban poor in project towns live in underserved areas where drainage 
is dysfunctional or nonexistent, flooding is frequent, access to solid waste collection is limited, 
sanitation is inadequate, and the environment is polluted because of poor toilet and septic tank 
facilities. About 21.2% of project beneficiaries are poor. Poverty rates in the six project towns 
are higher than the national urban average of 11.1% while poverty levels in the rural area of Phu 
Loc district is higher than the national average.  About 16.3% of the urban population in the 
project towns and about 40% of the residents in Chan May town and Phu Loc district are poor. 
The  Project  will  develop  and expand urban services to poor and low-income households, 
generate  new  employment  opportunities,  develop  community  ownership  and  self-reliance, 
reduce the risk of disease through health awareness programs, and ensure a sustainable 
environment. The Project will directly address one of the Millennium Development Goals and 
Targets (MDGTs) referring to sanitation improvements, and will contribute to achieving other 
MDGTs by improving health of the local population and reducing poverty and vulnerability. A 
summary poverty reduction and social strategy is presented in Appendix 4. A poverty and social 
analysis is presented in Supplementary Appendix C. 
 
32.  Gender. The issue of gender has received special attention during project preparation. 
Women are responsible for a variety of tasks relating to sanitation and waste collection at the 
community  and  household  levels.  More  than  half  of  the  URENCO  staff  in  project  towns 
employed as sweepers and waste collectors are women. Scavengers, collecting waste in the 
landfill sites, are mostly women. By occupying low-level jobs in institutions and communities, 
most women lack opportunities or capacity to hold managerial positions. Females tend to be 
underrepresented in decision-making positions, despite having a large membership base in the 
women’s union. The Project builds on the past experiences of the women’s unions in previous 
ADB-funded water supply and sanitation projects. Through part A, the Project will (i) provide 
institutional capacity building for the Women’s Union to ensure effective implementation; (ii) 
offer  coordinating,  financial,  and  management  opportunities  for  the  Women’s  Union;  (iii) 
increase  access  to  female  beneficiaries  of  poor  and  low-income  households;  (iv)  make 
provisions for increased gender awareness and representation within URENCO; and (v) work to 
enhance gender equality and women’s empowerment. A summary gender analysis and action 
plan is presented in Appendix 5 and a comprehensive gender analysis and action plan is 
presented in Supplementary Appendix D. 
 
33.  Involuntary Resettlement. The Project will involve land acquisition and resettlement of 
people and businesses. It will require acquisition of 138 hectares of land, of which 110 hectares 
is agricultural land that will be lost because of improvements in drainage and flood protection, 
wastewater  and  sanitation,  and  solid  waste  infrastructure.  A  total  of  2,337  households 
(approximately 10,571 people), including shops and businesses, will be affected, of which 1,100 
households, including shops and businesses, will be severely affected. The remaining 1,237 
households will be marginally affected. The cost of  resettlement of people affected by the

8 
Project is estimated at $7.7 million, including implementation costs and contingencies. The 
impact is significant due to the construction of landfill sites, wastewater treatment plants, dike-
roads, and flood-regulating basins. Community-based sanitation programs may require some 
land acquisition for the construction of drains, footpaths, or solid waste collection units.  
 
34.  Efforts have been made to avoid and, where possible, minimize the level of impact. 
Affected people will be compensated for their losses at full replacement cost, and provided with 
transition allowances and rehabilitation measures. Priority consideration will be given to affected 
people  who  participate  in  community  and  household  sanitation  programs  under  part  A. 
Additional support has been included for the poor, vulnerable, and female-headed households. 
A full resettlement plan for each of the project towns has been prepared based on inventory of 
losses and socioeconomic surveys, including focus-group discussions with affected people and 
local authorities. A resettlement framework has been prepared to guide any unforeseen land 
acquisition  and  resettlement  planning  during  project  implementation.  A  summary  of  land 
acquisition and resettlement is presented in Appendix 6. Resettlement plans for each project 
town and an overall resettlement framework are presented in Supplementary Appendix E. 
 
35.  Environment. The Project is classified as environment category B. The Project will not 
result in any serious negative environmental impacts because proposed project activities are 
designed to improve the quality of life and physical environment of the urban population, and the 
adverse environmental impacts arising from the design, construction, and operation of proposed 
activities will be temporary, minor, localized, and can be minimized to acceptable levels through 
mitigation measures and monitoring programs identified in an initial environmental examination 
(IEE). No project activities will be located close to or within designated environmentally sensitive 
areas such as national parks or natural resource conservation reserves. Each project town has 
prepared an IEE, including an environmental management plan (EMP), with the support of the 
consultants,  which  has  been  reviewed  and  approved  by  the  environmental  authorities 
concerned. PMUs and the departments of natural resources and environment (DNREs) in each 
province will regularly monitor all construction activities. Water-quality monitoring will be carried 
out  for  all  sewerage  treatment  plants  and  the  landfill  works  by  designated  environmental 
monitoring  laboratories  at  the  provincial  level.  In  accordance  with  ADB’s  requirements  for 
environmental  assessment,  as  well  as  government  regulations  on  environmental  impact 
assessment, an updated IEE for each project town will be submitted to the DNRE of each 
province and to ADB before civil works begin.   
 
36.  To ensure that all applicable national and provincial environmental laws, regulations, and 
standards—as  well  as  ADB  environmental  requirements—will  be  met  during  design, 
construction, and operation, an EMP for each project town has been prepared and will be 
carried out by the PMU at the provincial level, in collaboration with the DNRE concerned. During 
project preparation, local people have been informed about potential negative environmental 
impacts and mitigation measures included in the EMP, and the IEEs have been translated into 
Vietnamese. The PPC of each project province has assured ADB that  mitigation measures 
identified in the IEE will be incorporated into design, construction, and operation of subprojects. 
Environmental measures requiring action from contractors will be incorporated in civil works 
contracts. Implementation of proposed environmental mitigation measures will be monitored by 
the PMUs with the support of DNREs. Monitoring results will be reported to the PCU, MOC, 
Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, and ADB through semiannual progress reports 
on project implementation and annual reports on environmental monitoring.   
 
37.  To ensure that the IEE and EMP can be successfully implemented in each project town, at 
least one environment specialist will be placed at each PMU. An environmental capacity-building 
component to the PCU and the PMUs has been included. An appropriate budget has been included to 
implement proposed mitigation measures as well as capacity-building activities identified in the EMP.

A summary IEE is presented in Appendix 7. A summary EMP is presented in Supplementary 
Appendix F, and IEEs for each project town are presented in Supplementary Appendix G. 
 
38.  Community Participation. All project components were formulated after discussions with 
concerned government officials and consultations with affected communities and beneficiaries. The 
Project is designed so that it is responsive to the communities' needs, will function on a sustainable 
basis, and will have no adverse social or environmental impacts. The Project will promote grassroots 
participation  in  urban  infrastructure  planning  and  environmental  improvements  by  providing 
community groups with (i) adequate information about community and household sanitation programs; 
(ii) sufficient opportunities to participate during project preparation, implementation, maintenance, and 
operations; and (iii) concerted capacity building for poor and low-income communities in developing 
ownership and self-reliance. The scope of part A was tightened as a result of clear identification of the 
primary stakeholders, and extensive consultation with project beneficiaries through participatory 
approaches. Subsequent mechanisms to increase community participation will enable community 
groups and individual households to set their own priorities for urban environmental improvements, 
and to utilize and manage sanitation and solid waste subcomponents based on collective resources 
and contributions. Results of participation with affected people illustrate different community dynamics 
and reactions to resettlement as reflected in resettlement plans. Consultation with local communities 
on environmental issues has been incorporated into the IEEs and EMP.  
 
39.  Strengthening  of  Urban  Policies  and  Institutions.  The  Project  will  improve  the 
efficiency and sustainability of urban services in project towns by improving the institutional and 
operational framework for urban management and delivery of urban environmental services. At 
the national level, the Project will support MOC to prepare guidelines on urban management, as 
well as guidelines on drainage, sanitation, and solid waste tariffs. At the town level, the Project 
will support the urban management divisions of the TPCs to improve their capacities in urban 
planning and management, and to become efficient units able to monitor the quality and level of 
services delivered by URENCOs and other public or private service providers. 
 
40.  The Project will support the transformation of URENCOs into autonomous and efficient 
companies, accountable to the TPCs and their clients. The Project will promote institutional and 
legal reforms at the provincial level and provide technical support to URENCOs to allow them to 
(i) establish accounting systems and separate budgets and accounts following Vietnamese 
Accounting Standards for each of their main activities, distinguishing between (a) drainage and 
wastewater, (b) solid waste management, (c) other O&M activities, and (d) new construction 
activities; (ii) change the focus of URENCOs to management and O&M of urban infrastructure 
by  progressively  separating  construction  units;  (iii)  calculate,  recommend,  and  justify 
appropriate fees for drainage, wastewater, and solid waste to clients and people’s councils, and 
agree on appropriate service levels with TPCs; (iv) own equipment for O&M and keep sufficient 
funds for depreciation of equipment and repayment of loans;  (v) collect drainage and solid 
waste fees, retaining all revenues in two separate accounts and using them solely for O&M of 
the solid waste and drainage and wastewater facilities, respectively, under the responsibility of a 
URENCO; (vi) impose penalties on people who do not pay for services received, or destroy 
urban infrastructure under their responsibility; (vii) adopt and implement efficient and effective 
asset management procedures; (viii) prepare and adopt O&M plans, manuals, and procedures; 
and (ix) implement efficient financial and management information systems. 
 
41.  Improved Financial Sustainability of Urban Environmental Services. The Project will 
support  Government  policy  by  helping  URENCOs  generate  more  revenue  from  their  own 
sources,  and  gradually  reduce  Government  subsidies.  Tariffs  will  be  increased  so  that 
URENCOs can collect enough resources to pay all O&M costs and depreciation of O&M 
equipment for drainage, wastewater, and solid waste management. Recommended tariffs have 
been calculated so they are affordable to low-income and poor people. Water supply companies 
in each province will collect charges for drainage and wastewater services on behalf of the

10 
URENCO as a surcharge on the water tariff, then transfer the revenue to a dedicated account in 
URENCO. A new environmental fee or a surcharge on the land and property tax, which will 
apply to all households and organizations in the town, will be levied directly by the TPC to 
finance capital investments in urban environmental infrastructure. The URENCO will continue to 
collect charges for solid waste services directly from customers and will progressively increase 
those charges. The URENCO will sign service contracts with the TPC for the O&M of urban 
infrastructure, which will include payments from the TPC to the URENCO for providing services to 
the town without a direct cost recovery mechanism, such as street lights, road cleaning, parks, 
green areas, and cemeteries. The TPC will also continue payments to the URENCO for drainage, 
wastewater, and solid waste systems until the URENCO has reached full cost recovery through 
direct charges. All fees and payments from the TPC to the URENCO will be based on proper O&M 
and service levels, agreed between the TPC, URENCO, and users of the service. 
 
42.  Focus on the Central Region. To avoid the destabilizing effect of significant migration to 
Hanoi and HCMC, Viet Nam needs to develop a network of provincial and district towns in the central 
region that can provide economic opportunity and quality of life for a population gradually released 
from farming. The Project will support ADB’s overall strategy, as noted in the CSP, of focusing a 
significant part of its interventions on the central region. It will complement other ongoing and future 
ADB interventions in the central region to ensure more balanced regional economic development.

F.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Project Management 
46.  The PPC will be the executing agency in each project province. Each PPC has set up a 
provincial  project  steering  committee  (PSC),  which  will  have  overall  responsibility  for 
implementation  and  policy  guidance.  The  PSCs  comprise  senior  officials  from  the  PPCs, 
provincial departments of construction, departments of finance, departments of planning and 
investment, DNREs, TPCs, women’s unions, URENCOs, and the project director. The PSC will 
provide  policy  guidance,  and  coordinate  provincial  agencies  to  ensure  quality  and  timely 
implementation. Each PPC has established a PMU with full-time professional staff in each TPC, 
except Thua Thien Hue and Quang Ngai provinces, where PMUs have been established in the 
department of construction of the PPC and the URENCO, respectively. The PMU will support 
the PSC and will be responsible for daily implementation. The PMU will comprise staff from the 
TPC, URENCO, and other provincial, town, or district-level agencies, with expertise in project 
management,  drainage,  sanitary  engineering,  environmental  management,  accounting, 
community education, and development. 
 
47.  For overall project coordination at the national level, a project advisory committee (PAC) 
will be established, if necessary. The PAC will be convened, if requested by any of its members, 
to discuss common problems affecting implementation, and exchange policy, technical, and 
financial lessons learnt.  It will consist of one senior official from MOC as chairperson and 
personnel from the six project provinces as members. The PAC may invite other relevant 
ministries, ADB, or AFD staff to participate as observers. A project coordination unit (PCU) has 
been established in MOC  comprising full-time and part-time professional staff with adequate 
project experience and proficiency in English language. The PCU will act as a secretariat to the 
PAC and will be responsible for overall coordination of the Project; selection and management 
of consultants; handling of audited statements of project accounts; and consolidation of project 
reports to be submitted to ADB, AFD, and the Government. Other PCU functions include (i) 
developing a common accounting software for the PPCs, (ii) disseminating information on 
disbursement and withdrawal guidelines to PPCs and training staff in their use, (iii) keeping 
centralized registration of withdrawal applications and auditing, (iv) ensuring compliance with 
loan covenants, and (v) monitoring and evaluating project performance to ensure that the 
objectives are being met. 
 
48.  A community management committee (CMC), chaired by a senior member of the town’s 
women’s union, will be established in each province for overall managing and implementing of 
part A. The CMC will include representatives of the URENCO, TPC, and women’s union. Other 
mass organizations could also be invited to participate in the CMC on an ad-hoc basis. The 
women’s union in each town will be responsible for daily implementation activities under part A. 
The project management mechanism is presented in Appendix 9.

50.  Goods and works to be financed by ADB and AFD will be procured in accordance with

estimated to cost more than $100,000 equivalent but less than $500,000 equivalent. Equipment

direct purchase in accordance with procedures satisfactory to ADB. For the CBS component

towns,  the  Project  will  consider  funding  suitable  nongovernmental  organizations  or  mass 
organizations  to  work  in  a  collaborative  and  participatory  manner  with  local  communities 
following ADB’s community participation guide. 
 
51.  The ICB contracts are expected to include separate contracts in each province for 
(i) building drainage, flood protection, and wastewater works; (ii) O&M equipment for solid waste 
management; and (iii) O&M equipment for drainage and sanitation. The LCB contracts are 
expected to include (i) separate contracts in  each province for building landfills, solid waste 
storage stations, repair workshops, and landfill access roads; and (ii) separate LCB contracts in 
each province for building drainage and public sanitation facilities. Force accounts (i.e., for

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Social and Gender Impacts 
60.  The Project will directly benefit a total of 504,000 people in the six project towns, of 
which 50% are women. Rural population in the areas around these towns will also indirectly 
benefit. Reduced migration to Hanoi and HCMC because of improved quality of life in the 
project area will reduce pressure on Hanoi’s and HCMC’s  urban systems. Improvements to 
urban environmental infrastructure will bring about increased social benefits to local residents 
and communities and to the urban development sector in general. Inadequate infrastructure 
systems  pose  serious  environmental  and  health  risks,  and  inhibit  social  and  economic 
development.  The  Project  will  aim  to  reduce  environment-related  diseases,  lower  medical 
expenses, and lessen the impact of flooding on household incomes from lost working days and 
household damages. For the poor and low-income communities, the impact will be the most 
visible. Many reside in low-lying, flood-prone areas where improving drainage, sanitation, and 
solid waste systems are pivotal to improved health and hygiene.  
 
61.  Other social and gender benefits include increased community participation by the poor 
and women and enhanced self-reliance in urban environmental management. Women are 
responsible for a variety of tasks relating to sanitation at both the family and community levels, 
especially as sweepers and waste collectors employed by a URENCO. Increasing the role of 
women in urban management and institutions will (i) improve sanitation and public health 
practices, and (ii) strengthen the capacity of women to hold managerial positions and take 
ownership for small-scale urban environmental improvements within their communities. Through 
demand-based interventions, upgrading a small fishing village in Lang Co will have significant 
social and economic benefits, including the potential to participate in the tourism industry.

16 
 
B.   Economic Benefits 
62.  The  economic  analysis  has  been  undertaken  following  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  the 
Economic Analysis of Projects (1997) and ADB’s Framework for the Economic and Financial 
Appraisal of Urban Development Sector Projects  (1994). The analysis comprises least-cost 
analyses of alternative options for all project components and a cost-benefit analysis for the 
drainage component in each town. The major economic benefits arise from reduced incidence 
and severity of flooding. These have been quantified in terms of resource cost savings from 
avoided (i) damage to property; (ii) cleanup costs after flooding; (iii) time lost due to travel 
delays; (iv) lost employment opportunities; (v) loss of business income; (vi) medical costs and 
public  health  expenditure  related  to  waterborne  diseases;  and  (vii)  expenditure  on  the 
maintenance  for  roads,  drains,  and  other  municipal  infrastructure  damaged  by  floods. 
Nonquantifiable benefits include reduced threat of disruption to social activities and stress 
caused by such events to the urban communities. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) 
calculated for each town ranges from 16.4% to 21.1%. The sensitivities of the EIRRs of the 
drainage and flood protection components are tested against adverse changes in key variables. 
The result of sensitivity analysis shows that the Project is most sensitive to delays in project 
completion. However, all EIRRs exceed 12%. The economic analysis is presented in Appendix 
13; details are available in Supplementary Appendix L.   
 
C.  Financial Aspects 
63.  Financial analyses were conducted to determine the financial viability of the selected 
components and the sustainability of the six URENCOs. In addition, a financial internal rate of 
return (FIRR) is calculated for the solid waste management component in each town. For the 
drainage and flood protection component, the Project aims to directly recover, via water tariff 
surcharge, the full O&M cost, including the capital cost of the equipment for O&M purposes. 
Additionally, an environmental fee or a surcharge on the land and house tax will be levied by 
each TPC or PPC to recover an appropriate portion of capital costs.8 In 2004, all project towns 
will implement a 10% surcharge on the water bill, increase it to 20% in 2006, and increase it 
further to the level required for recovering the full O&M cost of the services in 2007.  
 
64.  For solid waste management systems, the Project aims for full cost recovery.9 To 
achieve this target, all project towns will apply a differentiated user fee for domestic, commercial 
and institutional, and industrial users starting from 2007. All project towns will increase the 
current solid waste user fee by 30% in 2004 and further 20% in 2006. The FIRRs calculated for 
the solid waste component range from 7.2% to 10.6%, all above the estimated weighted 
average cost of capital of 4.0% for the Project.  
 
65.  Affordability  analyses  have  been  undertaken  to  ensure  that  the  service  users, 
particularly the poor, can afford water surcharges for drainage and wastewater service and user 
fees for solid waste management. These fees were found affordable. The financial projections 
prepared for the six URENCOs  indicate that financial performance improves over the 2004–
2014 forecast period as drainage/wastewater tariffs are applied and solid waste tariff increases 
are implemented. The Government’s budget support to the services will be gradually reduced 
and finally eliminated in year 2007. The financial analysis is presented in Appendix 14; details 
are available in Supplementary Appendix M.

D.  Risks and Mitigation Measures 
66.  The  main  risks  associated  with  the  Project  are  (i)  limited  human  resources  and 
capacities of TPCs, URENCOs, and women’s unions; (ii) uncertainty regarding tariff increases 
necessary to ensure sustainability of urban services; (iii) insufficient community participation in 
project  implementation,  particularly  from  women  and  the  poor;  (iv) poor  and  vulnerable 
households negatively affected by resettlement; (v) delays caused by PMUs' lack of experience 
in managing ADB-funded projects; and (vi) lack of local government ownership of sanitation 
facilities. 
 
67.  The Project incorporates measures to mitigate these risks. They include (i) institutional 
strengthening for TPCs, URENCOs, and women’s unions to increase their managerial and 
operational  capacities;  (ii)  a  detailed,  time-bound  tariff  increase  program  for  urban 
environmental services, affordable to all citizens and agreed to by PPCs;  (iii) a participation 
program  and  gender  action  plan  and  public  awareness  campaigns;  (iv)  a  resettlement 
framework and resettlement plans to ensure that affected people will maintain or even improve 
their living standards after project completion; (v) the PCU and consultants with experience in 
implementing  ADB-assisted  projects  will  assist  PMUs  to  establish  effective  project 
management, reporting, and bidding procedures; and (vi) local ownership, ensured through 
PPCs’ commitment to tariff increases and allocating revenues for O&M.

A.  Specific Assurances 
68.  In addition to the standard assurances, the Government and PPCs have given the 
following assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents: 
 
(i)  The  Government  will  undertake  the  actions  described  in  the  policy  and 
institutional action plan (Appendix 3) within the agreed time frame, and will 
advise ADB of its progress through quarterly progress reports. 
 
(ii)  Within  3  months  of  loan  effectiveness,  each  PPC  will  establish  a  CMC  to 
overview part A of the Project in each province. The PPC will ensure timely 
disbursement of funds from the PMU to the town’s women’s union for activities 
under part A.

CMC  guidance,  and  in  consultation  with  the  PMUs,  local  authorities,  and 
communities—will develop an HSP to provide grants to low-income and poor 
households with conditions and eligibility criteria acceptable to ADB, which will be   
observed during project implementation.

sanitation, requiring such measures as (a) connecting sullage drains and septic 
tanks to drains in high- and medium-density areas, and to drains or properly 
designed  and  constructed  soakaways  in  low-density  areas;  (b)  that  each 
household or business located in high- and medium-density areas will have a 
septic tank that meets prescribed standards; and (c) that hotels, restaurants, 
hospitals, and industrial enterprises will have on-site treatment facilities to treat 
their wastewater.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Viet Nam: 
 
Viet Nam has experienced rapid urbanization and economic growth over the past decade, but urban and regional 
development has been unbalanced. The central region’s urban population is 4.5 million and is growing 4.5% per 
annum. In 1999, the central region accounted for 20.6% of the national population. Development in the central region 
has suffered and urban infrastructure is unable to meet the growing demand because of insufficient funds and weak 
institutional arrangements. Inadequate infrastructure systems pose serious environmental and health risks and inhibit 
social and economic development. This has fueled the rural to urban migration: the population of Hanoi and Ho Chi 
Minh City increased about 1.5 times in the past 10 years and accounts for 40% of Viet Nam’s total urban population.  
 
The Project will reduce flooding and improve drainage, sanitation, and solid waste systems in five provincial capitals 
and one district level town in the central region. Demand-based community awareness and pro-poor sanitation (APPS) 
programs will expand services to poor and low-income households and communities in remote and underserved 
areas. The Project will improve urban infrastructure systems and service coverage so that the five provincial capitals 
can function as sustainable regional economic centers, and the district town will be better able to develop its tourism 
potential and serve the surrounding poor fishing community. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Proposed Classification: Poverty Intervention 
Thematic Areas: Human Development 
 
The central region is one of the poorest in Viet Nam. The selected project towns experience levels of poverty where 
the urban living standard is poorer than the national average. According to the Viet Nam Living Standard Survey 
(VLSS), the national urban poverty average is 11.1%. About 21.2% of the total beneficiaries from the Project are 
expected to be poor. This percentage includes the total number of beneficiaries from the solid waste component in 
Lang Co that live in the Chan May urban area, Phoc Loc district, and four communes of the Phoc Loc district. There 
are also some households that reside just above the poverty line, and are equally susceptible to shocks, poor 
sanitation, and floods, all of which weaken their human capital, especially their health. 
 
The  Project  will  directly  address  one  of  the  millennium  development  goals  and  targets  (MDGTs):  to  ensure 
environmental sustainability. This includes reducing the risk of disaster from floods, and further impoverishment from 
poor drainage, sanitation, and solid waste collection. The majority of the urban poor work in unstable and low-paid 
jobs,  where  median  household  income  ranges  from  D400,000-800,000  per  month.  The  urban-poor  reside  in 
underserved areas where drainage is dysfunctional or nonexistent, access to solid waste collection is limited, 
sanitation is inadequate, and the environment is polluted due to the lack of appropriate toilet and septic tank facilities. 
They are up to 3.5 times as likely to experience flooding of their houses than nonpoor households, and are more 
vulnerable to shocks such as sickness due to poor sanitation or flooding. Environmental diseases have high economic 
and social consequences, including high medical expenses and lost working days that harm incomes and further 
marginalize the poor. 
 
The Project will reduce flooding and improve drainage, sanitation, and solid waste systems. Improvements made in 
environmental management further contribute to the achievement of other MDGTs. Improved sanitation and better 
drainage reduces (i) illnesses and mortality amongst different population groups, and (ii) the associated economic and 
social costs. Community-based interventions will expand services to remote and underserved communities, including 
resettlement areas. Poor households will benefit from these improvements, as they cluster in areas that are low-lying 
and poorly serviced by solid waste collectors. Community awareness and participation programs will educate and 
inform beneficiaries so that they are active participants in their own development. Community-based sanitation 
programs will strengthen community ownership and management of local environmental improvements, and the 
household sanitation program will increase septic tank coverage amongst the poor and low-income. Poor and low-
income  households,  especially  those  engaging  in  the  community-based sanitation program, will make special 
arrangements with urban environmental companies (URENCOs) to ensure affordable services.

A stakeholder analysis helped identify the key project stakeholders and their interests. Primary stakeholders include 
residents  in  urban  wards,  resettlement-affected  people,  the  Women’s  Unions,  URENCOs,  and  the  project 
management unit. Secondary stakeholders include the town people’s committees, mass organizations, ward people’s 
committees, provincial people’s committees, relevant line agencies, and the Ministry of Construction.   
 
Individual  subcomponents  for  each  project  town  were  identified  through  public  consultations,  workshops,  and 
meetings involving extensive stakeholder participation. Decree No. 29/1998/ND-CP, reiterated in the CPRGS, calls for 
increased citizen responsibilities through grassroots participation in utilizing and managing infrastructure projects. 
People are (i) given adequate information about development projects; and (ii) entitled to comment on and contribute 
to implementation, maintenance and operations, and express their role as the owners of subprojects. APPS will 
contribute to this democratization by providing information, generating awareness, facilitating community participation 
and consultation with URENCOs, and encouraging local solutions through demand-driven sanitation improvements. 
 
During project design, community meetings were held with beneficiaries to discuss flooding, sanitation, poverty, 
resettlement, affordability issues, and environmental concerns. Consultations with communities and beneficiaries 
revealed challenges, strategies, and solutions for project design and implementation. Socioeconomic surveys obtained 
information and individual views on current situations and future preferences. Similar surveys, including inventory of 
loss surveys, were conducted amongst resettlement-affected populations. Special consultations were also held with 
poor and vulnerable households, including female-headed households. Key stakeholder input and feedback in project 
design helped it evolve to its current state. 
 
A community participation strategy has been developed to take into account the different levels of cooperation and 
collaboration of stakeholders. Levels of participation include information exchange, consultation, collaboration, review 
and comments on reports, and empowerment. Weekly meetings, workshops, reviews, consultation meetings, technical 
work groups, and planning groups are the various forms of communications used to ensure active participation, project 
support, and productive feedback. Based on lessons learned, a community management committee in each Project 
town will be formed to (i) coordinate APPS, (ii) enhance community ownership at the local level, and (iii) provide 
financial support for community and household sanitation improvements. The community management committee will 
help increase accountability and distribute responsibilities among the Women’s Union, URENCO, and town people’s 
committee in each project town.

SUMMARY GENDER ANALYSIS AND ACTION PLAN 
 
A.  Background 
1.  Females comprise about 50% of the population, and female-headed households (FHHs) account 
for 29-40% of all households. In households where men are present but women serve as household 
heads, the women work longer hours and are more active in their communities than their partners. FHHs 
without male spouses account for about 8-14% of all households. The patriarchal system is strong, and 
with it comes a distinct gendered division of labor. Men and women are responsible for different types of 
productive work that define their social roles, while women are still responsible for domestic work, 
including a variety of tasks relating to sanitation. Poor women have little decision-making power, while 
women in middle-income families have a greater decision-making role and contribute more to household 
income.  
 
2.  The gendered division of labor within urban environmental companies (URENCOs) is clear. Men 
are given heavy work such as driving garbage trucks, dredging drains, working at landfills, and staffing 
the funeral division. Women sweep roads, collect leaves, cut tree branches, or serve in administrative 
roles as accountants, cashiers, or secretaries. About 60 scavengers, mostly women, rely on collecting 
scrap from landfill sites to supplement household incomes of about D30,000 per household per day. 
Scavengers must pay a fee of D1,000 per day to access the Thanh Hoa landfill site. 
 
3.  Although women are represented in large numbers in the Women’s Unions, gender disparities in 
leadership and decision-making exist at all levels in project towns. There are no female leaders in the 
town people’s committees, and an estimated 1-2% of women are vice chairpeople of ward people’s 
committees (Thanh Hoa and Dong Ha). More than half of URENCO staff is female (Thanh Hoa, Ha Tinh, 
and Dong Ha), but they  are inadequately represented at the management level. Women mainly head 
sanitation teams or groups. Women’s Unions are often the coordinating agencies for sanitation programs, 
environmental health campaigns, and household credit  programs in provincial towns. 
 
4.  Widows,  divorced  women,  and  FHHs  are  more  likely  to  experience  adverse  affects  of 
resettlement because they lack access to legal property rights and ownership certificates. They are more 
vulnerable, at greater risk of marginalization, and require additional support in terms of cash, labor, and 
technical advice. The summary gender action plan (Table A5.1) outlines how the Project will address the 
gender needs of workers and affected communities, with a particular focus on women.

development. The project’s main objective will be to provide improved environmental conditions 
and urban services in six project towns. 
 
3.  The  IEEs  follow  ADB’s  environmental  assessment  guidelines  and  government 
requirements.  The  IEE’s  objective  is  to  identify  potential  impacts,  evaluate their severity, 
recommend mitigation measures, and propose a monitoring plan for use during implementation. 
 
4.  PMUs in all provinces will update IEEs and environmental management plans (EMPs) 
for subprojects after detailed designs are complete, and will submit them to ADB and DNRE for 
review and approval. Government regulations require separate updated IEEs and EMPs for five 
proposed landfills (all except Quang Nam) and the wastewater treatment facility in Thanh Hoa. 
 
B.  Description of the Project 
   
5.  Long-term  project  goals  are  to  improve  quality  of  life  and  promote  economic 
development in the six project towns: Dong Ha, Ha Tinh, Lang Co, Quang Ngai, Tam Ky and 
Thanh Hoa. Specific project objectives are to (i) improve urban environmental conditions, and 
(ii)  improve  sustainability  of  the  urban  environmental  companies  (URENCOs)  and  urban 
services. 
 
6.  The  Project  will  include  three  major  physical  components:  (i)  drainage  and  flood 
protection, (ii) wastewater and public sanitation, and (iii) solid waste disposal. The drainage 
component will cover rehabilitating and cleaning 55 kilometers (km) of existing drains, building 
52 km of primary canals and culverts, building 166 km of primary and secondary drains, and 
110 km of tertiary drains. New wastewater treatment systems in Thanh Hoa (13,500 cubic 
meters (m3)/day) and Lang Co (4,750 m3/day) will cover collection, treatment, and disposal of 
wastewater for these two cities. Solid waste disposal covers the collection, transport, and 
disposal of municipal solid waste from the urban areas and selected communes in the provincial 
towns. The total project cost is estimated at $96.0 million equivalent.  
 
C.  Description of the Environment 
 
7.  All six towns are located along National Highway 1,160-1,020 km south of Hanoi on 
central Viet Nam’s flat coastal plain. The climate in all towns is similar: temperature varies only

slightly, although rainfall varies from a maximum annual average of about 3,400 mm in Lang Co 
to 1,750 mm in Thanh Hoa.  
 
8.  The  five  provincial  towns  are  all  on  near-flat  terrain,  located  5-15 km inland, and 
adjacent to major rivers, most of them tidal. The river floodplains are underlain by recent alluvial 
soils, whereas the towns generally sit on top of older alluvial soils. Dong Ha, by contrast, was 
built on clay residual soil. Lang Co’s project area is a long, narrow sand peninsula, its southern 
half between the Lap An Lagoon and the East Sea. Groundwater is the main water supply for 
Quang Ngai, and to some extent for Dong Ha. The other towns use surface water. 
 
9.  Surface  water  quality  will  be  most  affected  by  the  proposed  works.  Water  quality 
information and a limited program of field sampling and laboratory analysis were completed in 
April 2003 specifically for the IEE. The results of these investigations are presented in each IEE. 
The data confirms that many drains and receiving rivers are polluted. These investigations 
represent typical dry season conditions, where significant dilution and flushing is rare. 
 
10.  There are no known endangered flora or fauna in project areas. Most affected land has 
already been developed. Several sites of archeological or historical significance have been 
identified, and care will be taken to avoid affecting them during proposed works. Additional 
investigations during detailed design will ensure protection of historic sites. 
 
11.  The five provincial towns have populations ranging from 57,000 at Ha Tinh to 186,000 at 
Thanh Hoa. Lang Co, a district-level town, has a population of 11,000, but numbers are 
expected to grow substantially as tourism develops. The economies in provincial towns are 
based on services to surrounding rural regions. The main sources of jobs are provincial and 
district governments, market trade, and light industry such as furniture making, handicrafts, and 
food processing. Major industry is limited, although Quang Ngai is near an industrial zone 
associated with the Dung Quat oil refinery. In most communes, income comes from agriculture. 
Lang Co’s economy is based mainly on fishing, with tourism expected to dominate in future. 
 
D.   Screening of Potential Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
 
12.  In general, the Project proposes significant improvements to quality of life by upgrading 
infrastructure for drains, flood control, sewerage, solid waste collection, and disposal. The 
proposed works will also provide significant benefits to the physical and ecological environment. 
The Project may cause negative environmental impacts, but those are likely to be short-lived, 
minor, and limited by (i) carefully selecting project sites, (ii) seriously implementing proposed 
mitigation measures identified under the IEEs, (iii) regularly monitoring implementation of the 
EMP, and (iv) appropriate capacity building at the URENCOs. A summary of potential impacts 
and proposed mitigation measures is provided below. A detailed description of impacts is given 
in the EMP and the IEEs in Supplementary Appendixes F and G, respectively.  
 
1.  Location of Project Activities 
 
13.  Existing facilities, natural features, and topography dictate sites for drains and flood 
mitigation infrastructure. Drain improvements focus on the inner urban wards, whereas the solid 
waste  improvements  extend  to  the  communes.  Land  acquisition  for  drain  improvements 
involves about 60 hectares (ha) in total, with most affected area Ha Tinh, which severely affects 
206 households. Resettlement of 67 and 87 households, respectively, will also be necessary at 
Dong Ha and Tam Ky for new dikes and associated roads. Many others will be affected in those 
two towns. Compensation will be provided according to the resettlement plans.
