14.  Proposed wastewater treatment plants at Thanh Hoa and Lang Co will be remote from 
urban areas and will occupy about 12 ha and 6 ha respectively of marginal rice paddy fields and 
forest. The need for resettlement is quite minimal, although a number of fishermen near Lap An 
Lagoon in Lang Co may need to be compensated. 
 
15.  Landfill sites at Thanh Hoa, Ha Tinh, Dong Ha, and Quang Ngai have been selected 
adjacent to existing facilities. These sites were generally selected for their geological suitability, 
but continuing to collect leachate from existing facilities after closure will be  part of the new 
operations. In these towns, additional land has been acquired and only minor resettlement is 
required. The new landfill at Lang Co will require the acquisition of marginal agricultural land. 
Access roads leading to landfills at all towns except Tam Ky will be upgraded under the Project. 
Road alignments will generally follow existing tracks or master plan routes and will involve little 
land acquisition or resettlement. In most towns, roads will improve access to rural communities. 
 
2.  Design Aspects 
 
16.  Drain components are designed to reduce flooding, remove storm- and wastewater from 
towns, and discharge it in rivers, improving the environment and health conditions in each town. 
These works will not eliminate flooding but will significantly reduce severity and duration.   
 
17.  In Thanh Hoa and Lang Co, wastewater treatment facilities will improve surface water 
and groundwater quality. Treatment facilities will be designed to meet  Vietnamese standards 
recommended by the MNRE, and operations will be monitored to optimize performance and 
minimize risk to receiving water quality. Sludge will need to be carefully managed to ensure 
satisfactory performance. Guidance on this aspect is provided in the attached EMP.  
 
18.  In general, connecting industries to public sewers is sensible, reducing the number of 
discharge points and thus the complexity and cost of monitoring and enforcement. Absolutely 
critical to success, however, is formulating an industrial pretreatment program, including specific 
limits hazardous and toxic substances and other pollutants, as well as monitoring procedures 
and enforcement capability. 
 
19.  New landfills will include base liners, leachate drainage, and collection and treatment 
systems in accordance with Vietnamese standards. This, together with the natural clay soil 
beneath most landfill sites, will minimize the risk of any significant impact to the underlying 
groundwater or downstream surface water resources. An integral part of landfill design is the 
closure of existing landfills with clay capping, as well as improved leachate collection and 
treatment at the new adjacent facility. The net effect will be positive for the environment. A 
monitoring system needs to be established to measure effectiveness of mitigation.   
 
3.  Construction Activities 
 
20.  Much of the existing drain network planned for upgrading is located in densely populated 
urban areas. The excavation work involved in removing mud and sludge from existing drains 
and retention basins, natural ground from new pipeline routes, and the temporary storage of this 
material alongside the trenches, will result in some inconvenience to adjacent residents. Issues 
of traffic, noise, odor and localized machinery vibration have been identified. The construction of 
dikes  and  roads  will  also  involve  moving  earth,  with  the  potential  for  noise,  dust,  traffic 
congestion, erosion, and sediment contamination of waterways.

21.  Proposed  EMPs  under  the  IEEs  include  detailed  mitigation  measures  such  as 
requirements  for  prompt  removal  of  odorous  spoil  from  densely  populated  areas  and 
appropriate disposal.  The EMP also recommends restricted working hours and monitoring 
noise, dust, and vibration so that work practices can be modified accordingly. 
 
22.  Landfill construction will entail some noise and dust, but far from residential areas and 
with little negative impact expected. During the closure of old landfills, occupational health and 
safety measures will be needed to protect workers from contact with leachate and landfill gas. 
 
4.  Operation Activities 
 
23.  Capacity building at URENCOs will result in a regular maintenance program for drains 
so  they  do  not  deteriorate  to  their  present  extent.  This  will  also  significantly  improve 
occupational health and safety during maintenance.  
 
24.  At the wastewater treatment works, sludge will be collected periodically then dried and 
matured for several months prior to disposal. Screenings from plant operations will also be 
collected for disposal either onsite or at the landfill. Public sanitary facilities will have a positive 
impact. Proposed waste stabilization ponds are potentially odorous if not operated effectively. 
Procedures  for  operating  and  monitoring  pond  biochemistry  will  be  carried  out  to  ensure 
minimum odor. Discharge of plant effluent also will be monitored to ensure compliance with 
Vietnamese standards. 
 
25.  Improved waste storage facilities in communities, together with the proposed education 
program, will reduce waste dumped in drains and other low-lying areas. Landfill operation 
involves  some  hazardous  activities.  The  operator  will  be  required  to  follow  operational 
procedures identified under the IEE to ensure the design contains environmental protection 
measures. Occupational health and safety measures will be included to ensure a safe working 
environment for employees and scavengers. 
 
E.   Institutional Requirements and Monitoring Program 
 
26.  Each provincial people’s committee will be the executing agency in its province. Each 
executing agency will set up a provincial steering committee (PSC) and a project management 
unit (PMU). A project advisory council may be convened on an ad-hoc basis to review progress 
and resolve any problems arising during implementation. For overall project coordination, a 
project coordination unit (PCU) will be established in the MOC. The main functions of the PCU 
are to undertake coordination, consolidated project accounting, auditing and monitoring, and 
reporting to the MOC, ADB, and other government agencies concerned. 
 
27.  To ensure that ADB environmental requirements and all applicable environmental laws, 
regulations, and standards are met during design, construction, and operation, an EMP for each 
of six project towns has been prepared and will be carried out by the PSC/PMU at the provincial 
level,  in  collaboration  with  the  departments  of  natural  resources  and  environment  (DNRE) 
concerned. An integral part of the EMP will be environmental monitoring implemented by a 
designated environmental laboratory. PSC/PMU assured that the mitigation measures identified 
in  the  IEE  will  be  incorporated  into  design,  construction,  and  operation.  Environmental 
measures needing action from contractors will be incorporated in civil works contracts.

28.  PMUs, with the support of DNREs concerned, will monitor implementation of proposed 
environmental mitigation measures. Results will be reported to the PCU, MOC, MNRE, and 
ADB through semiannual reports on project implementation and environmental monitoring. 
 
29.  At least one environment specialist will be on staff at each PMU because the PSC/PMU 
lacks the professional capabilities to monitor IEE implementation. An environmental capacity-
building component to the PCU and PMUs needs to be included under the Project so that those 
directly responsible for implementation and monitoring the EMP can fulfill their responsibilities.    
 
F.   Findings and Recommendations 
 
30.  The various activities involved in the design, construction, and operation of the upgraded 
drainage, flood protection, sanitation, wastewater treatment, and solid waste infrastructure will 
have a significant positive impact on quality of life and the physical environment in all six towns. 
  
31.  Potential  adverse  impacts  have  been  identified,  such  as  those  associated  with 
construction. Other negative effects are associated with infrastructure operation. However, 
potential adverse impacts arising from the design, construction, and operation of proposed 
project activities will be temporary, minor, localized, and can be minimized to acceptable levels 
through mitigation measures and monitoring programs identified under the IEEs. Resettlement 
issues have been recognized and will be specifically addressed in the resettlement plans. 
 
32.  All six PMUs will prepare and submit updated subproject IEEs and EMPs for review and 
approval by ADB and DNRE following completion of detailed designs. In accordance with 
government legislation, separate updated IEEs and EMPs for each landfill and the Thanh Hoa 
wastewater treatment facility will be required at the detailed design stage. These will more fully 
evaluate the potential negative impacts of these facilities and further develop/update appropriate 
mitigation measures and monitoring. ADB and the DNREs concerned must approve the final 
IEE for each landfill and the wastewater treatment facility before construction can begin.    
 
33.  To minimize the potential harm to the Lap An Lagoon and achieve sustainable tourism in 
Lang Co, at least two alternatives for disposal of effluent from the wastewater treatment plant 
need to be studied during design. One option could be to reuse treated wastewater to irrigate a 
planned golf course. 
 
G.   Conclusion 
 
34.  The conclusion of this summary IEE, based on the IEEs for six project towns, was that 
the Project is unlikely to result in serious negative environmental impact. This is because (i) 
proposed project activities are designed to improve quality of life and physical environment, and 
adverse  environmental  impacts  arising  from  design,  construction,  and  operation  will  be 
temporary, minor, localized, and can be mitigated to acceptable levels; (ii) no project activities 
will be located close to or within environmentally sensitive areas; (iii) each project town has 
prepared an IEE, including an EMP, which will be reviewed and endorsed by the environmental 
authorities concerned; (iv) all construction activities be regularly monitored by the PMU and the 
DNRE; and (v) water quality monitoring be carried out for all sewage treatment plants and the 
landfill works by a designated, provincial-level environmental laboratory.  
 
35.  According to the above assessment and ADB’s requirements, a detailed environmental 
impact assessment is not warranted.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The economic analysis has been conducted following the ADB’s Guidelines for the 
Economic Analysis of Projects (1997) and the Framework for the Economic and Financial 
Appraisal of Urban Development Sector Projects (1994) to test the economic efficiency and 
viability of the Project. Least-cost analyses were undertaken for drainage, wastewater, and 
public sanitation, and solid waste subprojects. A cost-benefit analysis is carried out for each 
drainage subproject. The subprojects are evaluated over a period of 30 years with no 
salvage value assumed thereafter. 
 
B.  Least-Cost Analysis  
 
2.  Least-cost  analyses  were  carried  out  for  the  three  main  engineering  project 
components:  (i)  combined  drainage  and  wastewater  systems  and  flood  protection,  (ii) 
wastewater treatment in Lang Co and Thanh Hoa, and (iii) solid waste systems, with the 
development of sanitary landfills and upgrading and expansion of collection systems.  
 
  1.  Combined Wastewater/Drainage Systems and Flood Protection 
 
3.  The drainage subcomponents in the five provincial towns will improve the combined 
drainage systems as a first step toward long-term drainage master plans. Separate drainage 
and sewerage systems will be developed in Lang Co, in accordance with its master plan. 
Flood protection improvement will include the construction of dike roads and tide gates.  
 
4.  The capacity of the combined drain depends primarily on the design storm14 and 
catchment characteristics, as wastewater represent only a small percentage of the total 
conduit flows in the wet season. Design storm return periods adopted for the project are 2 
years for primary drains and 1-2 years for secondary and tertiary drains, in accordance with 
current practice in Vietnam. Designing for more severe events is not justified because the 
increased costs outweigh the benefits arising from less frequent flooding. 
 
5.  Based on the engineering design criteria, the best technical options have been 
selected providing the necessary combined drainage and flood protection in each town. In 
most cases, there are no discrete engineering alternatives, so the system is the least-cost 
option to meet drainage and flood protection requirements. 
 
6.  In the case of dikes in Tam Ky and Dong Ha, where these structures are designed to 
prevent annual flooding of residential areas located between the river and the main highway 
(built above the flood level), analyses shows these structures are the least-cost alternative 
when compared with the alternative of resettling all households in flood-prone areas. 
 
  2.  Wastewater Collection and Treatment  – Lang Co and Thanh Hoa 
 
7.  The wastewater subcomponent is designed to collect, treat, and safely dispose of 
wastewater from urban areas in Thanh Hoa and Lang Co. The works in Thanh Hoa include 
construction of interceptor chambers on the combined drains, close to their discharge points, 
to divert sewage flows to the interceptor sewer for treatment. The wastewater subcomponent 
in Lang Co will develop a separate sewerage system. The interceptor sewerage system and 
wastewater treatment facility are designed for projected wastewater flows in 2012 in Thanh 
Hoa and 2015 in Lang Co, with provision for expansion.

8.  The wastewater treatment works will comprise waste stabilization ponds (WSPs), 
which are widely used throughout the world. WSPs are simple to operate and maintain, 
require no electricity or chemicals, and will be designed to produce high-quality effluent that 
meets Vietnamese and international standards. These were shown to be the least-cost 
treatment option in each case. In Lang Co, alternatives included activated sludge treatment 
and a sea outfall, and in Thanh Hoa activated sludge treatment.  
 
9.  In  Thanh  Hoa,  comparison  of  combined  drainage  and  wastewater  system  with 
separate systems demonstrated that the proposed combined system was the least-cost 
option. In the case of Lang Co, comparison of the preferred collection system using septic 
tanks was compared with direct connection of households. While the results (within 10% 
difference) showed that the preferred option was least cost, it is recommended that the 
alternatives be examined in more detail by the detailed design consultant during project 
implementation. 
 
  3.  Solid Waste Management 
 
10.  To ensure that the solid waste component is the least-cost option, the following 
segments of the solid waste project were examined in each town: (i) initial waste storage and 
collection options, (ii) the need for transfer stations within the towns, and (iii) municipal solid 
waste treatment and disposal alternatives. 
 
11.  In each town, the collection of solid waste was examined. The ideal situation is where 
compactor trucks can pick up waste directly from bins. However, this is not possible in all 
towns because of local conditions (narrow lanes, uneven road and pavement conditions, and 
social factors such as vandalism.) The next least-cost collection method is by pedicart or 
handcart, with compactor trucks picking up solid waste from temporary collection stations. 
The size and number of compactor trucks was optimized based on local topography and 
volumes of solid waste to be collected. 
 
12.  Least-cost analyses demonstrated that permanent transfer stations were not justified 
in any towns because of the close proximity of the landfills. The least-cost options were 
temporary transfer stations where waste from pedicarts and handcarts are transferred to 
trucks for direct transport to landfill sites. Solid waste collected by compactor trucks from 
households or bins will be transported directly to the landfill site. 
 
13.  The options evaluated for treatment/disposal of municipal solid waste are sanitary 
landfills, incineration, and biological conversion. The least-cost analysis showed the landfill 
was the best option, followed by composting associated with landfill. The incineration option 
was the most costly. Sanitary landfills are therefore recommended for each town. 
 
C.  Cost-Benefit Analysis for Drainage Subproject 
14.  The cost-benefit analysis for drainage subprojects in each town was undertaken by 
comparing the cost and benefits under with- and without-project scenarios. The without-
project scenario refers to the continuation of the existing situation. The with-project case is 
established by appraising the costs and benefits of each of drainage subprojects. The 
subprojects  are  evaluated  over  a  period  of  30  years  with  no  salvage  value  assumed 
thereafter. 
  1.  Project Cost 
15.  The capital costs and incremental operation and maintenance costs of each drainage 
subproject have been considered. Economic costs have been derived from financial project 
costs. All costs are expressed in constant 2003 prices. Physical contingencies of 10% have 
been added to the base costs, and taxes and duties have been discounted as appropriate.

Tradable components have been adjusted to economic prices using the shadow exchange

16.  The subproject will generate benefits both to each town’s economy and to individual 
households and businesses. Drainage improvements will reduce incidence and severity of 
flooding and will therefore significantly reduce (i) flood damage to properties, (ii) post-flood 
cleanup costs, (iii) lost employment opportunities due to flooding, (iv) loss of income to 
businesses  (commerce  and  market  gardening),  (v)  sick  days  lost  due  to  waterborne

has been counted as a project benefit. In each town, the population in wards where annual 
flooding occurs has been identified. Households in these wards will benefit from reduced or 
eliminated flood damage and cleanup  cost. The benefits of less work lost, health costs 
saved, and travel delays avoided will accrue to the whole town as a result of floods that 
block roads, disrupt access to markets, schools, hospitals, and public services, and spread 
polluted water throughout towns.
